title: Thousands of alcoholics and drug addicts use their habits to receive the Disability Support Pension
text:
Thousands of alcoholics and drug addicts are using their habits to claim the Disability Support Pension, official figures have revealed.

There are currently 1277 DSP recipients who list their only medical condition as drug or alcohol dependence, The Courier-Mail reported.

The shocking data comes as Prime Minister Scott Morrison pushes to drug test welfare recipients receiving the Newstart and Youth Allowance.

Singles on the DSP can get $850 a fortnight and couples can receive $641 each, but the rates can be affected by the recipients age and living conditions.

There are currently 1277 DSP recipients who list their only medical condition as drug or alcohol dependence (stock image)

The DSP website says applicants could be eligible for the pension if their condition stops them working at least 15 hours a week over the next two years.

They are also required to meet an 'impairment rating' of 20 points based on the government's impairment tables.

There were 21,081 DSP recipients who had multiple drug and alcohol related conditions listed with the government in June 2012.

This number jumped an increase of almost 25 per cent in June this year to 26,248.

Families Minister Anne Ruston said: 'While the number of people on the Disability Support Pension with their sole medical condition listed as drug or alcohol dependence is reducing, we know there is more to do.'

'The Morrison Government's drug-testing trials will be another tool in our arsenal to deal with the scourge of substance abuse.

The data was revealed as Prime Minister Scott Morrison pushes to drug test welfare recipients receiving the Newstart and Youth Allowance

'We don't think that anybody should be taking an ­illegal substance because we understand it has a significant impact on their capacity to be able to function and to get a job, which is very important to their health and wellbeing.'

The two-year trials of drug testing welfare recipients would occur in Sydney's Canterbury-Bankstown area, Logan in Queensland and Mandurah in Western Australia.

More than 6,500 Youth Allowance or Newstart recipients from the trial areas would be asked to provide urine, saliva or hair samples when they apply for welfare if the laws go ahead.

If recipients tested positive to drugs, it would affect their payments for up to two years.
